Comment: Fun!

I wish you would also make a Reverse-mode variant, although it would need to be much simplified.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved the contribution ðŸ‘ðŸ»

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tedious but doable clash that covers a lot of basic operations
What does "sum each value with the key in the same position in keys" mean?

Goal
* Please clarify that the required hexadecimal digits are always in the range {{a}} to {{f}} only. Based on the current statement, it's reasonable for a player to assume that digits 0 to 9 may also be present, but this is not the case.

* Please change the following:

  â€¢ decimal => its decimal value
  
  â€¢ each digit => each value
  
  â€¢ and output it as char codes => . Interpret each number as a character code and output the corresponding ASCII characters joined as a single string.

Input
* Please change "List of keys" to "[[keys]], which is a list of integers".

Constraints
* Please specify the ranges of [[n]] and each value in [[keys]].

Cases
* Test 2 violates the first constraint.

* At present, four cases expect output containing characters other than lowercase English letters:
  - Validator 1
  - Test 4
  - Validator 4
  - Validator 5
  
  Just one "visible" test and three hidden validators in short. Note also that in Test 4, the "other" characters are all spaces, so it's not immediately obvious that other characters may appear in the output.
  
  Please rearrange the cases so that it's clearer that characters outside lowercase English letters can appear in the output. At the same time, ensure that each test matches its validator and covers the same scenario.

* Currently, Validator 5 is the only case where uppercase English letters appear in the output. Please modify Test 5 so that it includes such characters as well.

By the way, thank you for including me in a case ðŸ˜†

Thanks.

Done. These outputs were expected to contain characters that are not lower-case letters. I made the first constraint more specific. Hope It's clearer now.

Thank you.

Sorry for my bad English T^T.
Let's say `keys = [1, 2, 3]`.
So there is 3 hexadecimal digits in [[message]].
Let's say they are `hex = [a, b, c]`.
"Sum each value (a, b and c) with the key in the same position in keys (1, 2, 3)"
So result = [1 + a (10), 2 + b (11), 3 + c (12)] = [11, 13, 15].

Please, let me know if you understood.
Thank you ^-^
Thank you ^-^
Thank you ^-^

I see, thanks for the clarification :)

Perhaps it might be clearer to phrase the operation in terms of each hexadecimal character, e.g.: "For the [[i]]-th hexadecimal digit ({{a}} to {{f}}) that appears inside [[message]], you should add the corresponding [[i]]-th key value in [[keys]] to the decimal value of the digit."

You might also want to add an example to your goal section like you did above ^. E.g.,

<<Example>>
[[message]] = "a bouncr"
[[keys]] = [1, 2, 3]
hexadecimal digits: [a, b, c]
result = [1 + 0xa, 2 + 0xb, 3 + 0xc] = [11, 13, 15]
Thank you so much for this! I will be doing the changes now
Very cool formatting :) Thanks for the changes; the clash looks good to me

Thank you ^---^
I'm afraid the example made it too easy as it almost look like a pseudo-code.

Thank you for making the changes. I have just a few more requests:

Goal
* Please move "(a to f)" to appear before "inside" for clarity.

* Please add "and" before "sum".

Input
* Please add "space-separated" before "integers".

Constraints
* Please rearrange the constraints to appear in the same order as inputs.

* Please change 18 and 108 to 17 and 116 respectively. (These are the theoretical limits that ensure all characters in the output fall within the printable ASCII range.)

* Please add:
All characters in the output are guaranteed to be printable ASCII characters.

Thanks again.
Done. Thank you.

Oi, 5DN1L. Sorry to bother you Â´>_<
I don't know if the comments section has a ping system using the @ symbol, so, to be sure, I'm replying to this comment to let you know about the changes I made and if there is any problems with it.
No, unfortunately there isn't. So, thank you for replying to notify me! I'll take a look.

It looks fine overall, but taking a fresh look gives me a new idea: we should explicitly clarify that the keys are all decimal (base-10) values. Normally this wouldn't be necessary, but since this clash also involves handling base-16 digits, the distinction is worth noting in either the Goal section or the Input section or both.

Great suggestion.
Done.
Thanks.
